detail.abstract: Zanthoxylum armatum DC., commonly known as Timur, is a medicinally and culturally significant plant indigenous to the Himalayan region. Traditionally utilized in Ayurveda, Unani, and various ethnic systems of medicine, the plant has been extensively valued for its culinary use and its therapeutic applications in treating dental disorders, digestive complaints, inflammation, and infections. This chapter provides a comprehensive review of the phytochemical diversity and pharmacological potential of Z. armatum. The plant is rich in bioactive constituents including alkaloids (e.g., berberine, chelerythrine), flavonoids, terpenoids, glycosides, phenolics, tannins, and essential oils containing compounds such as linalool, limonene, and β-caryophyllene. Scientific studies have demonstrated its broad-spectrum antimicrobial, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antidiabetic, hypolipidemic, and gastroprotective properties. In addition, emerging evidence supports its roles in immunomodulation, neuroprotection, and potential anticancer activity. Traditional and modern dosage practices are discussed along with considerations for safety, toxicity, and regulatory aspects. Despite its therapeutic promise, gaps remain in clinical validation, standardization, and toxicity profiling. The chapter emphasizes the need for integrated research efforts to fully harness the nutraceutical and pharmaceutical potential of Z. armatum while promoting its sustainable utilization and conservation.

title: Taxing Crypto-Asset Transactions- Foundations for a Globally Coordinated Approach (Book Review)
affiliations: Singapore Management University - Yong Pung How School of Law

detail.title: Taxing Crypto-Asset Transactions- Foundations for a Globally Coordinated Approach (Book Review)
detail.abstract: With the total market capitalisation of crypto-assets amounting to trillions of US dollars, it is clear that crypto taxation needs to be taken seriously by both tax administrations and taxpayers. Over the past few years, numerous tax administrations around the world have devoted resources to crypto taxation, as evidenced by the substantial amount of guidance that has been made available to taxpayers. International organisations such as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the United Nations have also released publications on crypto taxation. Despite all these domestic and international efforts to provide guidance on crypto taxation, there remains considerable uncertainty as to the tax treatment of crypto-assets and transactions. In the first chapter of this excellent book by Shaun Parsons, the current situation is summed up concisely, highlighting “global tax confusion over the treatment of crypto-assets”, absence of a globally coordinated approach, and “lack of consensus about what those tax consequences should be”.

title: Impacts of Coal Fire at Dump Slope Toes on Slope Stability in Arid Open-Pit Mines and a Targeted Control Method
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Impacts of Coal Fire at Dump Slope Toes on Slope Stability in Arid Open-Pit Mines and a Targeted Control Method
detail.abstract: During open-pit mining, end-dumping of waste material against the pit wall commonly results in the formation of reverse composite slopes. These slopes exert shear stress on shallow-buried coal seams and overlying strata at the slope toe, leading to fracturing and crack propagation. This structural damage facilitates spontaneous combustion of the coal seam, forming coal fire zones that significantly increase the risk of dump slope instability. To address this geotechnical hazard, this study proposes a control technique—the slope toe counterweight method—for preventing coal fires at the toe of dump slopes. Based on Coulomb earth pressure theory, analytical formulas for the geometric design of the counterweight platform are derived to support engineering applications. A case study from an open-pit coal mine in Xinjiang, China, is presented. Field investigations combined with numerical simulations were conducted to analyze the formation mechanisms of coal fires at the waste dump slope toe and their effects on slope stability. The proposed method was implemented in the open-pit mine, and its performance was evaluated. Results demonstrate that the counterweight platform effectively reduces shear deformation, suppresses crack development, and blocks oxygen ingress, thereby controlling coal fire spread and mitigating slope instability risks. Additionally, the method significantly enhances slope stability. This study offers a practical, economical, and efficient engineering solution for coal fire prevention at dump slope toes and provides theoretical and technical support for coal fire mitigation in arid-region open-pit mines.

title: Text Augmentation for Vision: Modality-Preference Aware Few-Shot Learning
affiliations: Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University and Xidian University

detail.title: Text Augmentation for Vision: Modality-Preference Aware Few-Shot Learning
detail.abstract: Recent advances in vision-language models such as CLIP show great potential for few-shot learning, but their performance declines under extreme low-shot scenarios due to limited supervision and inherent modality imbalance. To address this, we propose a modality-preference aware framework with textual augmentation to enhance vision-centric few-shot image classification. By treating text descriptions as auxiliary training samples, our method enables effective and scalable augmentation without generating synthetic images. We introduce a training strategy called Alternating-Modality Supervision (AMS), where vision and text samples alternately supervise a shared classifier. We further observe that vision and text favor different loss functions: cross-entropy (CE) for vision and mean squared error (MSE) for text. Based on this, we propose Modality-Preference Loss Assignment (MPLA), which aligns each modality with its preferred objective and improves optimization stability. Extensive experiments on diverse datasets and backbone architectures confirm that combining MPLA with AMS improves few-shot performance and demonstrates strong generalizability.

title: Hqd-Em: Robust Vqa Through Hierarchical Question Decomposition Bias Module and Ensemble Adaptive Angular Margin Loss
affiliations: Sejong University and Sejong University

detail.title: Hqd-Em: Robust Vqa Through Hierarchical Question Decomposition Bias Module and Ensemble Adaptive Angular Margin Loss
detail.abstract: Recent studies in Visual Question Answering (VQA) have revealed that models often rely heavily on language priors rather than vision-language understanding, leading to poor generalization under distribution shifts. To address this challenge, we propose HQD-EM, a unified debiasing framework that combines Hierarchical Question Decomposition module (HQD) with an Ensemble adaptive angular Margin loss (EM). HQD systematically decomposes questions into multi-granular representations to capture layered language biases, while EM leverages bias confidence to modulate per-sample decision margins dynamically. Our method integrates generative bias modeling with adaptive margin learning in an end-to-end trainable architecture. Experiments on VQA benchmarks demonstrate that HQD-EM significantly outperforms prior work and achieves state-of-the-art results on VQA-CP2 and VQA-CP1.

title: The Role of Environmental Groups in Local Fracking Regulation
affiliations: Oregon State University and Oregon State University

detail.title: The Role of Environmental Groups in Local Fracking Regulation
detail.abstract: Hydraulic fracturing (fracking) is often considered the most important innovation in the energy system in the last five decades. Despite substantial research on the impacts of fracking on various economic outcomes, the literature has been largely silent on the subject of regulation. Fracking has been largely exempted from federal environmental legislation. This has allowed state and local governments to regulate fracking activities with a high level of heterogeneity, which ranges from passing resolutions that do not have actual consequences to outright bans. Over the ten years between 2009 and 2018, the number of local regulations increased from 12 to 387. We examine what drives local fracking policies, with a focus on the role of nonprofit environmental organizations in the passing of such regulations. We constructed a novel panel data set that includes information on the presence of fracking regulation in each community and on the activities of environmental groups. We develop a two-way fixed effects model to estimate the effect of environmental groups on the likelihood of a community adopting fracking regulations. Our results show that the presence of environmental groups and their expenditures increase the likelihood of communities adopting fracking regulations.

title: Query Expansion with Topic-Aware In-Context Learning and Vocabulary Projection for Open-Domain Dense Retrieval
affiliations: Xidian University, Dalian University of Technology, Xidian University, Xidian University and Xidian University

detail.title: Query Expansion with Topic-Aware In-Context Learning and Vocabulary Projection for Open-Domain Dense Retrieval
detail.abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have recently emerged as pivotal components in opendomain question answering. This study proposes a simple yet effective method to enhance dense retrieval using topic-aware In-Context Learning (ICL) and topic keyword projection. First we leverage LLMs to generate a pseudo-passage based on topic-aware demonstrations obtained from the pre-trained cluster to which the target query belongs. Second, we employ the masked language model (MLM) header in the autoencoder LM to map the query representation to implicitly topic-related tokens as keywords. We combine these two approaches to augment the original query. Extensive experiments on four prevalent open-domain question answering (ODQA) datasets demonstrate that our method achieves an average of 4.26% improvement in R@20 compared to state-ofthe- art query expansion work. Further analysis shows that the relevant demonstrations can provide higher-quality pseudo-passage generation, and the extracted keywords provide an interpretable basis for the effectiveness of dense retrieval. Code and data are available at https://github.com/XD-BDIV-NLP/TDPR.

title: High Speed, Low Impact? Evaluating Forest Impacts from Construction and Operation
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Duke Kunshan University and Duke University - Policy, Economics, Environment

detail.title: High Speed, Low Impact? Evaluating Forest Impacts from Construction and Operation
detail.abstract: Transport infrastructure for moving people and goods is critical for economic development. However, such investments also affect land use and forest cover by raising access to remote areas. Thus, when siting transport infrastructure, development-environment tradeoffs arise. We examine forest impacts for China’s world-leading investments in high-speed rail (HSR) during 2004-2022, showing and exploiting the exogeneity of HSR arrival in forested areas between end-point cities which drove HSR siting. We find that HSR’s construction phase, often involving ‘feeder’ roads, raised deforestation by 0.2% per year on average (higher for early construction years). In contrast, operation of HSR did not harm forest, on average. For the relatively rare HSR areas with low forest cover, deforestation from construction was higher (~ 0.5% per year) and this additional forest loss continued during operation. These findings suggest that targeted HSR siting, combined with care during construction, can yield high speed with low impact.

title: Llm-Assisted Labeling and Transformer Model Ensemble for Disaster-Related News Classification in Korean Regional Media (2011–2024)
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Llm-Assisted Labeling and Transformer Model Ensemble for Disaster-Related News Classification in Korean Regional Media (2011–2024)
detail.abstract: Timely situational awareness is critical during disasters, and news media serve as a vital source for rapid and reliable disaster-related information. However, existing news-mining studies primarily focus on a limited set of natural hazards, often neglecting diverse man-made disasters. To address this limitation, we propose a hybrid classification framework combining commercial API-served large language models (C-LLMs) and open-source fine-tunable pre-trained language models (F-PLMs) to classify 31 diverse disaster types. We first automatically labeled 56,563 stratified news headlines from 2.77 million articles using two C-LLMs (GPT-3.5-Turbo and Gemini-2.0 Flash-Lite). Human reviewers manually adjudicated only discrepant cases (19.1%), significantly reducing manual labeling effort. This labeled dataset was then used to fine-tune two transformer-based F-PLMs (BERT and KoELECTRA), which were combined into a soft-voting ensemble. The ensemble achieved a Macro-F1 score of 0.9589, closely approaching the best-performing C-LLM (Gemini, 0.9817). Temporal analysis of classified news articles showed strong alignment with 92 official activation dates of Korea’s Central Disaster and Safety Countermeasures Headquarters, validating the framework’s real-world applicability. The proposed hybrid approach is currently utilized by Korea’s National Disaster Management Research Institute for real-time disaster news monitoring and serves as one of the essential references for governmental disaster-budget prioritization.

title: Βetas Distribution and ETF Tracking Error
affiliations: ALBA Graduate Business School and University of Edinburgh

detail.title: Βetas Distribution and ETF Tracking Error
detail.abstract: We measure the effect on the tracking error of indexed, sampling-based exchange traded funds’ (ETFs) from the changing variation in the empirical distribution of the betas for the index’s constituent stocks. We find that the tracking error is positively related with increased variance in the distribution of betas of the index’s constituents when the ETFs are pursuing a sampling strategy, rather than an exact replication of the index. Unlike the extant literature on ETF tracking error that primarily focuses on market frictions, our results are novel by highlighting the importance of the design of an ETF in the magnitude of its tracking error.

title: IPO, Labor Investment Efficiency, and Performance Reversal
affiliations: Xiamen University, Xiamen University and Toronto Metropolitan University (formerly Ryerson University)

detail.title: IPO, Labor Investment Efficiency, and Performance Reversal
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the impact of going public on startups’ post-IPO labor investment efficiency, a crucial aspect of optimizing corporate resource allocation. Using a sample of IPO firms listed in Chinese stock market, we find that, compared to the period before the IPO, entrepreneurial firms experience not only an exacerbation of labor overinvestment post-IPO but also a mitigation of labor underinvestment. However, the severity of exacerbated labor underinvestment is more pronounced and offsets the benefits of alleviated labor underinvestment, ultimately leading to labor investment inefficiency. The post-IPO liquidity and empire-building effects explain the labor investment inefficiency. Heterogeneity analysis reveals the reduced labor investment efficiency post-IPO is more pronounced among non-SOEs, firms with higher cost of borrowing and poorer corporate governance, and those with pre-IPO suspension and favorable pre-IPO market performance. Further analysis indicates the inefficiency of labor investment post-IPO tends to hinder the long-term financial performance, triggering post-IPO performance reversal.

title: Financing Infrastructure Development Through Resource Rents: Is There a Curse?
affiliations: Omar Bongo University, Laboratory and Technical Analysis Office  (LABAT)

detail.title: Financing Infrastructure Development Through Resource Rents: Is There a Curse?
detail.abstract: This study tests the resource curse hypothesis by analysing the direct effect of rent financing on infrastructure development in the 24 most resource-rich African countries between 2005 and 2021 (with an average rent level of 10%). In order to assess the indirect role of financial development in this relationship, we incorporate the six financial development indicators from Sahay et al (2015). Thus, based on a correctly specified two-stage GMM system (Blundell and Bond, 1998), we find a negative and significant relationship between total resource rents and the African Infrastructure Development Index. More specifically, dependence on resource rents prevents the most resource-rich countries from financing their infrastructure development, thus confirming the natural resource curse hypothesis. Furthermore, our results reveal the moderating role of financial development in that a developed financial sector mitigates the negative effect of rents on infrastructure development.

title: Home Purchases with and Without Mortgage Credits: Implications for Portfolio Investment
affiliations: Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey and ADA University

detail.title: Home Purchases with and Without Mortgage Credits: Implications for Portfolio Investment
detail.abstract: This paper explores the impact of home purchase on the portfolio allocation of U.S. households, as buying a home is one of the largest purchasing decisions over the life cycle. An instrumental variable estimation method is applied to the Panel Study of Income Dynamics data to show significant differences in the portfolio behaviors of households prior to the purchase decision. While liquidity-constrained households who are planning to purchase a home with mortgage loans save mostly in the form of risk-free assets, liquidity-unconstrained households who are planning to purchase a home without any mortgage loans save mostly in the form of risky assets. We further employ and compute a parsimonious model of house purchasing decision to show that the aforementioned portfolio allocation differential can be captured with reasonable parameterizations. These results may imply that an optimal portfolio allocation for liquidity-constrained households could help them purchase the same home earlier or buy a larger home with the same duration of mortgage.

title: Comprehensive Performance Benchmarking and Comparative Analysis of Active Ransomware Threats
affiliations: Edinburgh Napier University and Edinburgh Napier University

detail.title: Comprehensive Performance Benchmarking and Comparative Analysis of Active Ransomware Threats

keywords.keywords: Ransomware Performance and BehaviourRansomware Execution BenchmarkingTest Dataset Generation and EvaluationRansomware DetectionCyber SecurityRansomware MitigationMalware

detail.abstract: Ransomware remains a pervasive cybersecurity threat, causing significant financial and operational disruptions across industries. Modern variants employ sophisticated encryption techniques, selective file targeting, and rapid execution strategies, leaving victims with minimal response time. Yet, limited research compares the performance of different strains in terms of encryption speed, execution efficiency, and system impact factors vital for effective attack prevention and mitigation. Current studies focus largely on detection and mitigation, with little attention to ransomware's operational efficiency. The absence of standardised, freely available, datasets further impedes comparative benchmarking, and recent advancements in encryption methods necessitate updated evaluations of execution times, speeds, and resource utilisation. This study addresses these gaps through a comprehensive benchmarking analysis of active ransomware threats. A novel dataset of 29 active ransomware strains was developed, and a controlled testing environment was established to systematically analyse their execution behaviour. A structured target dataset simulating real-world file systems was also created to facilitate robust comparative analysis. Key performance metrics, including encryption speed, execution time, and thread utilisation were evaluated using these datasets within a virtualised, isolated test environment. The dataset generation followed best practice principles, ensuring reproducibility and both datasets are freely available to the research community. Empirical results reveal significant variations, with encryption speeds ranging from 33 MB/s to 2.79 GB/s. The fastest strain, Trigona, achieved an encryption rate 84 times higher than the slowest, CL0P, highlighting diverse optimisation strategies. Distinct behavioural patterns, such as pre-encryption delays and multi-threading utilisation, substantially influence performance, offering critical insights into ransomware evolution and underscoring the need for adaptive defences. This work offers three key contributions: a comprehensive dataset of active ransomware, a realistic target dataset, and a rigorous benchmark analysis of ransomware performance. Collectively, these contributions provide a valuable opportunity for the cybersecurity community to refine detection tools, optimise system performance, and enhance proactive prevention measures.

title: Strip–Till Farming: Combining Controlled–Release Blended Fertilizer to Enhance Rainfed Maize N Use Efficiency While Mitigate Nr Footprint and Carbon Footprint in the Hilly Region of Northeast China
affiliations: Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University and Inner Mongolia Agricultural University

detail.title: Strip–Till Farming: Combining Controlled–Release Blended Fertilizer to Enhance Rainfed Maize N Use Efficiency While Mitigate Nr Footprint and Carbon Footprint in the Hilly Region of Northeast China
detail.abstract: Agricultural intensification in Northeast China's hilly rainfed regions is hindered by low maize productivity and high environmental costs caused by unscientific farming and fertilization practices. The exploration of tillage methods and corresponding fertilization modes aimed at enhancing maize nitrogen use efficiency and economic benefits, while reducing environmental costs in this region. A field experiment (2021-2022) employed two principal factors: A) Tillage systems: The differences between strip–till (RST) and conventional ridge cropping (CP), straw off-field no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with straw mulching (RNT) were comparatively investigated in the conventional fertilizer (Sd) mode. B) Fertilization regimes under RST: conventional fertilization (Sd), controlled–release urea blends (30%Cr, 50%Cr), and nitrogen–free control. Life cycle assessment (LCA) and Z-score analysis were used to evaluate environmental impacts, yield, nitrogen use efficiency, economic benefits, and overall maize production performance. RST significantly outperformed CP by 46.6% in yield, 62.0% in nitrogen use efficiency (NUE), and 8.2% in net economic benefits. Concurrently, demonstrated 4.9% and 4.7% reductions in Carbon and Nr footprints respectively. Under strip-till, the 50%Cr treatment increased yield, NUE, and net economic benefits by 48.9%, 8.8%, and 11.9% over Sd; reduced nitrogen loss, NH3 volatilization, and N2O emissions by 21.3%, 52.0%, and 8.6%; and lowered Carbon and Nr footprints by 11.4% and 38.9%, respectively. This study shows that RST combined with 50%Cr boosts yield and reduces environmental impacts in rainfed maize systems, offering practical solutions for ecological intensification and sustainable development in Northeast China's fragile agroecosystems.

title: A New Benchmark for Human Action Recognition with Moving Cameras
affiliations: National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University and National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University

detail.title: A New Benchmark for Human Action Recognition with Moving Cameras
detail.abstract: Although skeleton-based human action recognition (HAR) has been widely studied, most existing models are designed for static cameras. With the growing use of mobile devices, HAR under moving cameras remains underexplored due to challenges in dataset collection and robustness to motion. In this work, we propose an inexpensive-yet-e!ective synthesis method that converts static-camera 3D skeleton data into 2D/3D moving-camera data, establishing the first comprehensive benchmark for this setting.We show that 2D and 3D HAR models su!er accuracy drops of 3~5% and 10~15% respectively under moving cameras, mainly due to missing keypoints and inconsistent views. To address this, we propose a new preprocessing method that converts skeletal data into Gaussian-Blurred Connected Heatmaps (GBCH), apply a masked autoencoder on GBCH, and design a multi-modal transformer model with hybrid attention. Our method outperforms state-of-the-art 2D HAR models in both static and moving-camera scenarios.

title: Bridging the Ceo-Worker Pay Gap: Evidence from the Pay Ratio Mandate
affiliations: Washington State University and Washington State University

detail.title: Bridging the Ceo-Worker Pay Gap: Evidence from the Pay Ratio Mandate
detail.abstract: We examine whether, and at what point in time, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission’s (SEC) 2015 CEO-to-worker pay-ratio mandate is associated with changes in vertical pay dispersion. Leveraging both the rule’s staggered reporting schedule and a subset of firms where there is enough data to estimate the pay-ratio prior to the official disclosure, we compare “initial reporters” (December year-end firms) with “delayed reporters” in a dynamic difference-in-differences framework. Estimated pay ratios track closely before 2015 but differ by roughly 67 percent following the rule’s adoption—two years before companies were first required to disclose—suggesting that firms began adjusting after regulatory certainty, not implementation. The effect concentrates in consumer-facing firms and those led by younger CEOs, consistent with reputational risk and customer pressure. Overall, the evidence is consistent with the view that even a simple, non-monetary disclosure requirement can coincide with narrower pay gaps ahead of formal implementation, particularly where reputational channels are strong.

title: Financial Statement Disaggregation and Deposits: Evidence from the Expansion of Bank Call Reports
affiliations: University of New Mexico - Robert O. Anderson Schools of Management

detail.title: Financial Statement Disaggregation and Deposits: Evidence from the Expansion of Bank Call Reports
detail.abstract: Banks are required to report financial statements and related information in publicly available quarterly Call Reports. Over time, regulators have significantly expanded the required disclosures in these reports, allowing depositors to access more detailed information about banks. This study examines whether the disaggregation of financial information in Call Reports is relevant to depositors. By analyzing the number of publicly available Call Report items accessible to depositors and examining uninsured deposit flows at a macro level for each quarter from 1991 to 2024, this study provides evidence that the expansion of Call Reports leads to an increase in the volume of uninsured deposit flows. This effect is particularly noticeable in smaller banks, banks with lower capital ratios and weaker loan portfolio quality, as well as privately held banks. A classification of the disclosures reveals that the disaggregation of assets, liabilities, and off-balance sheet activities is the primary driver of this effect.

title: The Influence of the Landscape and Removal Efforts on the Economic Damage of the Invasive Wild Pig
affiliations: Mississippi State University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State University and Mississippi State University

detail.title: The Influence of the Landscape and Removal Efforts on the Economic Damage of the Invasive Wild Pig

keywords.keywords: Wild pig (Sus scrofa)Invasive speciesCrop damageAgricultural economicsSpatial Ecology

detail.abstract: Using reports of wild pig (Sus scrofa) damage provided by landowners in the Mississippi Alluvial Valley, we estimate financial costs across the landscape and assess the relationship with crops planted and local pig removal events. We found that pig removal conducted a year prior to damage reports has a significant effect on reducing damage among nearby properties, and that closer removal events are associated with less damage. Using detailed removal data, we estimated the cost of land trapping wild pigs to be $200 per pig, which is substantially less than the cost of pig damage without trapping.  Using data from both land trapping and aerial gunning, we estimate each pig removal within 1km of a property to be associated with a large reduction (approximately 40%-60%) of damages, per pig removed. Furthermore, high-value crops and agronomic fields for wildlife serve as attractive food sources for wild pigs and consumption of crops is responsible for the greatest financial damage in local areas.

title: Self Supervised Networks for Learning Latent Space Representations of Human Body Scans and Motions
affiliations: University of Houston, Florida State University and University of Houston

detail.title: Self Supervised Networks for Learning Latent Space Representations of Human Body Scans and Motions
detail.abstract: This paper introduces self-supervised neural network models to tackle several fundamental problems in the field of 3D human body analysis and processing. First, we propose VariShaPE (Varifold Shape Parameter Estimator), a novel architecture for the retrieval of latent space representations of body shapes and poses. This network offers a fast and robust method to estimate the embedding of arbitrary unregistered meshes into the latent space. Second, we complement the estimation of latent codes with MoGeN (Motion Geometry Network) a framework that learns the geometry on the latent space itself. This is achieved by lifting the body pose parameter space into a higher dimensional Euclidean space in which body motion mini-sequences from a training set of 4D data can be approximated by simple linear interpolation. Using the SMPL latent space representation we illustrate how the combination of these network models, once trained, can be used to perform a variety of tasks with very limited computational cost. This includes operations such as motion interpolation, extrapolation and transfer as well as random shape and pose generation.

title: Tax Burdens and Political Corruption: Evidence from the Salt Deduction Cap
affiliations: Carson College of Business, Clemson University - Wilbur O. and Ann Powers College of Business - Department of Finance, Washington State University and McCombs School of Business, University of Texas at Austin

detail.title: Tax Burdens and Political Corruption: Evidence from the Salt Deduction Cap
detail.abstract: We investigate whether tax burdens affect political corruption. Higher tax burdens could increase government corruption by lowering after-tax income and incentivizing corruption. Alternatively, higher tax burdens may decrease corruption by increasing citizen political engagement and monitoring of politicians. We use the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act's (TCJA's) $10,000 cap on state and local tax (SALT) deductions and cross-county differences in property tax levels as plausibly exogenous variation in tax burdens. We find that future local political corruption convictions are associated with a 4.3% for every 1% increase in tax burdens. Further, we document that increased tax burdens raise voter turnout. We examine four different cross-sections of the data and find that the corruption reduction is more pronounced when expected. Together, our results provide evidence that tax burdens increase civic engagement and citizen monitoring of public officials, which in turn could contribute to lower corruption.

title: Distributionally Robust Mean-Expectile Portfolio Optimization Under Wasserstein Metric
affiliations: Guru Gobind Singh Indraprastha University, Netaji Subhas Institute of Technology (NSIT) - Netaji Subhas University of Technology, University of Brescia and Department of Economics and Business

detail.title: Distributionally Robust Mean-Expectile Portfolio Optimization Under Wasserstein Metric
detail.abstract: Portfolio optimization problems with expectile risk measures have been well established in recent studies, although their solutions are mostly based on assets’ empirical distribution from historical returns. On the other hand, data uncertainty significantly impacts portfolio selection and affects optimal weights and then optimal decisions for small perturbations of the joint distribution parameters. We propose to formulate the mean-expectile portfolio optimization problem under a distributionally robust framework induced by the Wasserstein metric. The resulting robustified model with random variables supposed to be discretely supported reduces to a linear program for a given risk-return trade-off parameter, irrespective to the norm used in the Wasserstein metric needed to define the corresponding uncertainty set, and therefore, it is computationally efficient. We further carry out an extensive set of computational investigations under two different norms, l1 and l2, across four global financial markets featuring distributionally robust portfolios with expectile risk measures. As a result, the proposed robust model outperforms the nominal counterpart, showing stable investment gains. However, when compared to the distributionally robust version of the much popular Mean-Conditional Value-at-Risk portfolio optimization model, the performance seems to depend on the underlying norm taken in the definition of their respective Wasserstein uncertainty set.

title: Loss Given Default (Lgd)-Driven Interpretable Model Framework for Analyzing Farmers’ Credit Risk Feature Selection
affiliations: Northwest Agriculture and Forestry University, Teesside University, Shandong Agricultural University and Northwest Agricultural and Forestry University

detail.title: Loss Given Default (Lgd)-Driven Interpretable Model Framework for Analyzing Farmers’ Credit Risk Feature Selection
detail.abstract: The traditional default status-driven model for farmers’ credit risk feature selection is difficult to really distinguish the credit risk differences of different defaulting farmers. Moreover, it is difficult for the traditional model to solve the problems of poor credit risk assessment caused by imbalanced data and poor interpretability of the model. Therefore, this paper designs an LGD-driven interpretable model framework for farmers’ credit risk feature selection. According to two groups of real farmers’ loan data from different commercial banks, it is found that the framework designed in this paper has stronger ability to identify default risk than the traditional default status-driven model. And we found that the feature under the repayment ability criterion layer have the highest impact on farmers’ default losses.

title: Migrant Remittances and Regional Economic Disparities
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Université Jean Monnet Saint-Étienne

detail.title: Migrant Remittances and Regional Economic Disparities
detail.abstract: The distributional impacts of remittances at the subnational level remain underexplored. We examine how migrant remittances influence regional inequalities in income, assets, education, and healthcare by analyzing panel data from 109 Pakistani districts drawn from three household surveys and remote sensing data. We employ an instrumental variable strategy using instruments including distance to the nearest international airport interacted with transaction costs, global oil prices, and GDP of GCC countries. We find that 1) remittances increase income inequality. A 1 percent rise in recipient households raises the Gini index by 0.49–0.62 and MLD by 0.38–0.54 percentage points. This effect plateaus beyond a 24% threshold. 2) Remittances widen home ownership inequality but reduce it for non-farmland assets. 3) They boost school enrolment and reliance on private schools at primary and secondary levels. However, gender disparities widen. 4) We find no significant effect on healthcare inequality or gender gaps in access.

title: Life Assessment of Precision Resistors Based on Pso-K-Means and Convlstm Algorithms
affiliations: China Electronic Product Reliability and Environmental Testing Research Institute, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Xidian University

detail.title: Life Assessment of Precision Resistors Based on Pso-K-Means and Convlstm Algorithms
detail.abstract: Precision resistors in quartz accelerometer I/F conversion circuits are critical components whose degradation directly impacts the testing accuracy of quartz accelerometers. In order to predict and evaluate their remaining useful life with higher accuracy, this paper proposes a method for predicting and evaluating the RUL of precision resistors based on PSO-Kmeans and ConvLSTM algorithms. An accelerated life test (ALT) was designed for precision resistors, analyzed the degradation data in the ALT, and verified that the prediction accuracy of the method improves prediction accuracy by up to 40 % compared with conventional curve-fitting methods, and demonstrates feasible prediction of both RUL and activation energy. The method and its evaluation conclusions provide theoretical reference and data support for the reliability research and life prediction of similar electronic components.

title: Optimizing Multi-Agent Behavior for Interactive Autonomous Driving with Equilibrium Value Estimation
affiliations: Tongji University, Tongji University, Tongji University, Tongji University and Tongji University

detail.title: Optimizing Multi-Agent Behavior for Interactive Autonomous Driving with Equilibrium Value Estimation
detail.abstract: The safe deployment of autonomous vehicles (AVs) into real-world traffic requires robust interaction with human drivers exhibiting heterogeneous behavioral tendencies, spanning from rational cooperation to adversarial aggression. Existing methods often lack the capacity to systematically model such behavioral diversity, limiting their applicability for rigorous evaluation of AV. To address this challenge, we propose a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework that generates diverse interactive traffic through Estimation-Guided Policy Optimization (EGPO). Central to EGPO is the Equilibrium Value Estimation (EVE), a learnable hyperparameter that weights the outputs of the rational value function and the adversarial value function, reconstructing the policy's estimation of the expected reward. Notably, EVE is globally updated using meta-learning during policy learning. Furthermore, an EVE-guided policy network is used to feature multi-head architectures that efficiently process high-dimensional multi-agent observations while dynamically prioritizing context-specific features aligned with the learned EVEs.Extensive experiments conducted in both urban and highway scenarios demonstrate that EGPO produces traffic environments with enhanced behavioral controllability and diversity. Furthermore, EGPO excels in the closed-loop AV testing on OnSite benchmark, outperforming SOTA methods based on deep learning and rule-based  in terms of both realism and testing efficiency. Overall, EGPO offers a scalable and robust solution for simulating realistic interactions among diverse driving tendencies, facilitating the development of AV systems capable of handling complex real-world corner cases.

title: Transparency in Local Government: Theory and Evidence
affiliations: University of Valencia, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Jaume I University - Department of Economics and University of Granada

detail.title: Transparency in Local Government: Theory and Evidence
detail.abstract: Transparency is vital to good governance as it ensures accountability, integrity, and citizen participation. However, measuring transparency remains a challenge due to the ambiguous nature of human language. Traditional measurement approaches rely on binary or categorical dimensions, which can lead to limited insights and inaccurate policy decisions. To address this challenge, we develop a transparency indicator based on multiple metrics. On the one hand, fuzzy metrics are employed to quantify categorical dimensions; on the other hand, standard metrics are used to compute the overall transparency indicator. The notion of transparency is contrary to the binary principle of having a property or not, that is, to be transparent or not. In our case, we apply a novel methodology designed for formative measurement and partially compensatory models using a set of qualitative dimensions. This tool provides a measure of how close (observations close to 1) or far (observations close to 0) each observation (in this setting, the municipality) is from the analyzed concept. This is calculated for each indicator while preserving the metric structure. In the municipality setting, this approach captures the complexity of transparency and can better identify areas for improvement in local governments. In a second step, we analyze the political, economic, and social determinants of this transparency index, relying on spatial econometric techniques to account for spatial dependencies and to ensure the accuracy of our findings. We use a novel dataset that comprehensively measures transparency at the municipal level in the Valencian region. As far as we know, this is the first database that covers all municipalities in the region. By capturing the complexity of transparency, our approach can better identify areas for improvement and lead to more effective policy interventions. We argue that traditional approaches that rely on binary or categorical variables may oversimplify the concept, resulting in inadequate policy solutions that fail to address the real challenges faced by local governments.*Daniel Aparicio-Pérez, Maria Teresa Balaguer-Coll and Emili Tortosa-Ausina acknowledge the financial support by MCIN/AEI/10.13039/501100011033 (Ministerio de Ciencia e Innovación, PID2020-115450GB-I00). title: Nitrogen Fertilization Induces Greater Loss of Base Cations and Accumulation of Exchangeable Acids in Acidic Soils than in Neutral Soils

detail.title: Nitrogen Fertilization Induces Greater Loss of Base Cations and Accumulation of Exchangeable Acids in Acidic Soils than in Neutral Soils
detail.abstract: Agricultural soil acidification affects 40-70% of croplands worldwide and is rapidly intensifying with increasing nitrogen fertilization. Although nitrogen fertilizer-induced acidification has been widely documented, the coupled dynamics between base cations and exchangeable acids, particularly their quantitative relationships and thresholds across different soil pH levels, remain poorly understood. This study conducted a comprehensive meta-analysis of 2,348 sets of field trial data from 157 sites worldwide to reveal the acidification mechanisms under long-term nitrogen fertilization in soils with different pH levels. Quantifying the dynamic relationship between base cations (K⁺, Ca2+, Mg2+) and exchangeable acids in acidic and neutral soils through meta-analysis. This study aims to: (1) quantify the effects of nitrogen fertilizer on base cations and exchangeable acids; (2) evaluate the relationship between base cations loss and pH decline in soils with different pH values; (3) explore the mechanism by which organic matter alleviates the increase in exchangeable acids. The results showed that under nitrogen fertilization, the exchangeable K+, Ca2+, and Mg2+ decreased significantly in acidic soils by 20.3%, 48.6%, and 43.3%, respectively, but showed relative lower decreases in neutral soils by 17.9%, 14.5%, and 6.3%, respectively. In addition, the exchangeable acid content in acidic soils increased significantly by 116.5%, which was much higher than that in neutral soils (35.7%). Subgroup analyses revealed that the accumulation of exchangeable acids could be effectively inhibited when the soil organic matter content exceeded 25.0 g/kg; moreover, the addition of calcium was of great significance for the retention of soil organic matter. This study emphasizes that acidic soils are more sensitive to nitrogen fertilization than neutral soils and more susceptible to soil acidification. These findings are crucial for understanding the acidification threshold of nitrogen fertilizer application, accumulative effects of fertilization time, and dynamic equilibrium between base cations and exchangeable acids in soils with different pH values. They also provide scientific evidence for quantifying the threshold of organic matter content for acidification relief and mitigating soil acidification caused by nitrogen fertilization.

detail.title: Atypical Borrowing by Resource-Based Firms: Implications for Resource Curse
detail.abstract: We model the borrowing behavior of firms in natural resource sectors. Their optimal leverage increases with the policy rate, increasing more if the institutional environment is weak. Analysis of firm-level data on leverage, banking association, and policy rates in India supports our hypotheses. The results continue to hold in an international sample of 21 countries. Extension of the analysis to international data using macro-aggregates of leverage and LIBOR provides additional support. This aberration in the borrowing behavior of natural resource firms has implications that can aggravate the resource curse in resource-rich economies.

detail.title: Determination of AU in Gold Ores Based on Ew-Topsis Integrated Model by Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry
detail.abstract: Background Active carbon enrichment flame atomic absorption spectrometry (FAAS) has significant advantages in the analysis of rock and mineral samples due to its wide determination range, good reproducibility and high accuracy. However, there are many influencing factors in the analysis process and it is not easy to be controlled, so it is of great significance to study the process factors and propose the optimization of analysis parameters. Results Here, we propose to optimize the conditions of activated carbon enrichment-FAAS based on entropy weight(EW) theory and technique for order preference by similarity to ideal solution (TOPSIS) integrated model: Initially, single factor experiments were carried out on the conditions such as activated carbon consumption, ash content, adsorption column layers and washing solution temperature in the analysis process, to determine the most suitable condition range; Subsequently, the mixed orthogonal of four factors and four levels was established with the absolute value of the relative error(RE) of the determination results of three different contents of 51.8 µg g-1, 18.3µg g-1 and 1.1 µg g-1 as the experimental index; Thereafter, the EW algorithm was used to standardize the experimental data, and the weights of each index were determined to be 0.3120, 0.3219 and 0.3661, respectively; Once more, the TOPSIS model was used to construct the weighted specification matrix and determine the positive and negative ideal solutions, calculate the Euclidean distance and determine the relative closeness coefficient of each index, respectively; Ultimately, the optimal condition parameters were obtained by range analysis of the significant effects of activated carbon dosage, ash content, adsorption column layers and washing solution temperature. The findings demonstrated that the RE and relative standard deviations (RSD) of the method were 0.11%-4.69% and 0.43%-8.35%, respectively, under the optimized parameters for the preparation of 8 parallel samples and calculation of the performance indexes for the gold ore standards GBW(E)070012a, GBW07808b, GBW07809a and GBW07810, which were in accordance with the Geology and Minerals Industry Standard of the People's Republic of China (DZ/T 0130.3-2006). Significance and Novelty It indicated that the optimized analysis conditions by FAAS based on EW-TOPSIS integrated model was scientific and reliable, which fulfilled the analysis requirements of gold in rocks and minerals samples, and could be widely used in the production tasks of geological laboratories.

detail.abstract:
This chapter evaluates the autonomous business entity of the 21st century, embodied in the decentralized autonomous organization, or DAO, as a case study of knowledge commons. DAOs rely primarily on socio-technical infrastructures supplied by blockchain technology rather than on human-and-law corporate governance based on human beings and law. As systems for resource governance within financial and commercial contexts, DAOs ostensibly improve entity decision making at scale by reducing or even eliminating weaknesses implicit in reliance on human judgment.

Because DAOs consist substantially of combinations of shared computer code and shared data, we consider them using the Governing Knowledge Commons (GKC) research framework. We contrast the GKC perspective with long-standing views of the corporate form as representing one among several related modes of resource governance: as a nexus of contracts, as an instance of hierarchy and decision theory, and as a complex system. We situate our analysis in the context of earlier work on the corporation as commons. The chapter concludes that the GKC framework focuses attention on elements of governance that often are not salient in conventional accounts of the corporation: how governance responds to and generates social dilemmas associated specifically with practices of sharing knowledge, information, and data.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the effects of exchange rate fluctuations on cross-border consumer spending in small open economies. Exploiting a large, unexpected and persistent central bank-induced exchange rate appreciation and drawing on a unique dataset of over 500 million anonymized debit and credit card transactions, I document a substantial and immediate impact on both cross-border shopping by domestic consumers and tourism spending by foreign consumers. The strongest spending adjustments are observed among domestic consumers living near the border and foreign consumers from neighboring countries. Furthermore, foreign consumers from neighboring countries exhibit high exchange rate sensitivity on both the extensive and intensive margins and shift their consumption from higher- to lower-value goods and services. These findings suggest significant substitution effects in consumption on impact and emphasize the important role of cross-border shopping in small open economies. The paper provides insights for policymakers and central bankers, especially in small open economies where the exchange rate channel is an important channel of monetary policy transmission.

title: Bandwidth Selectors on Semiparametric Bayesian Networks

detail.title: Bandwidth Selectors on Semiparametric Bayesian Networks

keywords.keywords: Semiparametric Bayesian networks - Multivariate kernel density estimation - Bandwidth selection - Cross-validation - Plug-in

detail.abstract: Semiparametric Bayesian networks (SPBNs) integrate parametric and non-parametric probabilistic models, offering flexibility in learning complex data distributions from samples. In particular, kernel density estimators (KDEs) are employed for the non-parametric component. Under the assumption of data normality, the normal rule is used to learn the bandwidth matrix for the KDEs in SPBNs. This matrix is the key hyperparameter that controls the trade-off between bias and variance. However, real-world data often deviates from normality, potentially leading to suboptimal density estimation and reduced predictive performance. This paper first establishes the theoretical framework for the application of state-of-the-art bandwidth selectors and subsequently evaluates their impact on SPBN performance. We explore the approaches of cross-validation and plug-in selectors, assessing their effectiveness in enhancing the learning capability and applicability of SPBNs. To support this investigation, we have extended the open-source package \texttt{PyBNesian} for SPBNs with the additional bandwidth selection techniques and conducted extensive experimental analyses.  Our results demonstrate that the proposed bandwidth selectors leverage increasing information more effectively than the normal rule, which, despite its robustness, stagnates with more data. In particular, unbiased cross validation generally outperforms the normal rule, highlighting its advantage in high sample size scenarios

detail.abstract: This chapter uses the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, known as the IPCC, to illustrate and advance the idea of the expert knowledge commons. The IPCC was established in 1988 as an intergovernmental body of the United Nations, charged with advancing scientific knowledge about climate change in order to inform public policy decision making. As an institution and instrument of authority grounded in scientific expertise, the IPCC has come to play a critical role in advancing political, cultural, and economic awareness of the character of climate change. The IPCC has been the subject of a great deal of research, none of which has focused directly on the manner in which its authoritative status rests both formally and informally on multiple layers of shared knowledge, information, and data. This chapter uses the IPCC's governance of that shared knowledge to motivate and illustrate a model of expert knowledge commons.

detail.abstract: Objectives: The study explored healthcare workers’ experiences using the AfyaPro Connected Care app and identified key enablers and barriers to its adoption for diabetes and hypertension care in Ghana.Methods: A qualitative study was conducted with 20 healthcare workers from two healthcare facilities. Semi-structured interviews, guided by the Technology Acceptance Model, explored perceptions of the app’s usefulness, ease of use, and behavioural intention. Interviews were transcribed verbatim and analysed thematically.Results: Participants viewed the app positively, noting improvements in care delivery, communication, and patient engagement. Its user-friendly interface supported integration into routine workflows. However, barriers included unreliable power and internet access, digital challenges among older users, and unclear roles for junior staff. Suggestions included improved supervision, role clarity, targeted training, and decision-support features for junior staff.Innovation: The study adopted a user-centered, context-sensitive approach focused on real-world provider experiences. It illustrates how mHealth tools developed elsewhere can be adapted to low-resource settings. Proposed innovations include digital literacy training, role-specific decision support, and blended care models. These frame innovation as both technological adaptation and strategic system design.Conclusions: Healthcare workers found the mHealth app feasible and acceptable. The findings highlight the potential of digital tools to improve chronic disease care in resource-limited settings.

title: Resonance in Message Propagation to Improve Gcn Performance on Semi-Supervised Node Classification

detail.title: Resonance in Message Propagation to Improve Gcn Performance on Semi-Supervised Node Classification
detail.abstract: Graph convolutional network (GCN) has shown significant potential in semi-supervised node classification (SSNC). However, the message passing mechanism allows each node to aggregate messages from its neighbours and update its representation by indiscriminately averaging the messages. Stacking convolutional layers to access multi-hop messages and mixing messages from nodes in different classes easily cause over-smoothing. Additionally, without leveraging abundant unlabelled nodes intentionally, GCN trained by limited labelled nodes is prone to overfitting. We overcome these limitations by creating resonance in message propagation between node pairs in the same class. The new mechanism yields better node representations because it expands message access and enhances useful messages. The farther resonance propagates, the more unlabelled nodes participate in training. Moreover, a regularisation item is adopted to avoid incorrect and excessive resonance. The effectiveness of message resonance is theoretically proven and verified in SSNC experiments.

detail.abstract: This article introduces a formal typology of executable legal speech. Building on the concept of the regla compilada (compiled rule), it identifies the syntactic conditions under which a legal expression becomes executable by non-human systems. The analysis distinguishes declaration from compiled legal language and proposes four structural criteria for computability: position within the Chomsky grammar hierarchy, closure of rule structure, level of semantic ambiguity, and determinism of parsing. Instead of interpreting legal meaning, the article isolates the formal properties that permit legal norms to function as executable code. The objective is to define a machine-readable grammar of authority in which execution displaces interpretation, and structural form triggers legal action.

title: Motivations for Being Informal Carers of people Living with Dementia: A Systematic Review 2018 -2024

detail.title: Motivations for Being Informal Carers of people Living with Dementia: A Systematic Review 2018 -2024

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: This project was jointly funded by the University of Sussex and the University of Brighton.

detail.abstract: Background: Informal caregivers play a critical role in providing continuous, unpaid care to individuals with dementia, helping to improve their quality of life and reduce the demand on formal care services. The caregiving relationship is a complex, dyadic process that can profoundly affect both the caregiver and the care recipient, underscoring the need to alleviate caregiver burden and support their well-being. Understanding the motivations behind why individuals take on caregiving roles is essential, as it can predict their experiences, perceptions, and the overall impact of caregiving on their lives. A systematic review by Greenwood and Smith identified key motivators for informal caregivers. Additionally, substantial evidence shows that cultural perspectives and social values significantly influence caregiver experiences and motivations. Methods: This systematic review aimed to update the findings of Greenwood and Smith by examining recent research on the motivations behind caregiving across different demographics, ethnicities, and cultures. Six electronic databases were searched from August 2018 to January 2024. Titles and abstracts were screened using machine learning methods (ASReview), and a subset of full texts underwent duplicate screening. Eligible studies were appraised using the Mixed Methods Appraisal Tool (MMAT), and data were extracted and organised into thematic categories. Results: The initial search yielded 1,843 articles, of which 37 studies met the inclusion criteria after deduplication and screening. Cultural explanations for caregiving motivations included familism, ethnic identity, cultural values and beliefs, a sense of obligation, and personal fulfilment. Discussion: Cultural perceptions and social values significantly shape caregivers' experiences and perceptions, influencing families' engagement with and acceptance of formal care and support services. These findings highlight the need for further research to guide the development of culturally sensitive psychosocial support interventions tailored for diverse caregiving populations. Such personalised approaches are essential for reducing caregiver burden and fostering an inclusive caregiving environment that respects caregivers' unique motivations and values from various cultural backgrounds.

title: Future of AI in Management

detail.title: Future of AI in Management
detail.abstract: The rapid evolution of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is significantly transforming the landscape of management across industries. As AI technologies become increasingly sophisticated, they are reshaping decision-making processes, operational efficiencies, and organizational strategies. This paper explores the future of AI in management, analyzing its potential to revolutionize key management functions, including leadership, strategic planning, human resources, marketing, and operations. By examining current trends and technological advancements, the research identifies the ways in which AI can enhance business performance, drive innovation, and enable data-driven decision-making. Additionally, it explores the role evolving of managers in an AI-driven world, highlighting the new skills and leadership required to achieve the intersection of human intelligence and machine learning.

title: Tariff Shocks Weaken Dollar Dominance

detail.title: Tariff Shocks Weaken Dollar Dominance
detail.abstract: This paper exploits the quasi-natural experiment of U.S. reciprocal tariffs to provide the first causal evidence that trade shocks weaken global demand for dollar assets, even during financial turmoil. We find that this decline is driven by the erosion of the dollar’s role in trade invoicing and financing—mechanisms that typically underpin its safety status, but amplify vulnerability when trade linkages are disrupted or alternatives emerge. Our findings support recent theories linking the resilience and fragility of dollar dominance to its foundations in global trade. This study also highlights a potentially unintended consequence of aggressive trade policies in undermining the international monetary system’s stability.

title: Navigating the Twin Transformation: A Multi-Level Perspective on the Interplay between Digital and Sustainability Dynamic Capabilities
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Nyenrode Business University, Nyenrode Business University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Navigating the Twin Transformation: A Multi-Level Perspective on the Interplay between Digital and Sustainability Dynamic Capabilities
detail.abstract: In this paper, we provide a conceptualization of the pathways towards twin transformation by analyzing the required dynamic capabilities for digital and sustainability transformations, as well as their synergetic potential. We do so using an enhanced multi-level perspective to map the needed dynamic capabilities addressing imperatives of the niche, ecosystem, regime, and landscape levels. We deepen our analysis by qualifying these dynamic capabilities as being either similar, additive or dissonant (three synergetic dimensions). Our analysis shows that, while there are overlaps in dynamic capabilities, much of what is needed towards a twin transformation is additive or dissonant. This nuances a mainstream narrative of a perfect marriage between digital and sustainability transformations. Our analysis provides guidance for organizations developing the adequate dynamics capabilities towards a twin transformation and to identify potential dissonance to resolve.

title: A Knowledge-Based Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm for Multi-Objective Inventory Routing Problem

detail.title: A Knowledge-Based Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm for Multi-Objective Inventory Routing Problem
detail.abstract: In this study, we investigate the multi-objective inventory routing problem, which involves optimizing two competing objectives. The first objective is to minimize the total costs, considering time-dependent transport times and costs. The second objective is to maximize customer satisfaction by reducing the gap between product delivery times and predefined service times. To address this problem, we employ a knowledge-based Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) within a matheuristic framework, combining both heuristic and mathematical programming approaches. This method integrates a neighborhood-based crossover and a knowledge-based mutation to explore high-potential areas of the solution space. The effectiveness and performance of our proposed algorithm are demonstrated through the analysis of Pareto front solutions and the calculation of the hypervolume indicator, which is used to assess the convergence and quality of the solutions.

title: A Solution to the Order Picking Problem for Mixed Shelves Storage Strategy (Msss) Using Adaptive Simulated Annealing: How Well Does the Msss Perform Considering Pick-Face Blocking?

detail.title: A Solution to the Order Picking Problem for Mixed Shelves Storage Strategy (Msss) Using Adaptive Simulated Annealing: How Well Does the Msss Perform Considering Pick-Face Blocking?
detail.abstract: Order picking under the mixed-shelves storage strategy (MSSS) poses unique challenges: distributing stock-keeping units (SKUs) across multiple locations improves accessibility but complicates routing and intensifies congestion and pick-face blocking when multiple pickers operate simultaneously. This paper introduces a mixed-integer programming (MIP) model that captures multi-picker interactions under the MSSS and incorporates a novel scatteredness metric to guide SKU dispersion. We solve the MIP using Adaptive Simulated Annealing and conduct computational experiments varying picker counts. Results show that, compared to dedicated storage, MSSS can substantially reduce picker travel distances yet may incur significantly higher pick-face blocking, an effect that accelerates as the number of pickers increases. Our findings quantify these trade-offs and offer some managerial implications.

title: A Simulation-Optimization Approach for Perishable Supply Chains: Integrating Dynamic Shelf-Life and Disruption Recovery Strategy
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Simulation-Optimization Approach for Perishable Supply Chains: Integrating Dynamic Shelf-Life and Disruption Recovery Strategy
detail.abstract: Perishable food supply chains need to manage time-sensitive quality decay, stochastic demand, and transport delays. This paper introduces an integrated, stochastic simulation-optimization framework that jointly optimizes replenishment quantities, dynamic shelf-life decisions, and disruption recovery via adaptive pricing. First, a mixed-integer linear program capturing quality-adjusted pricing, holding and disposal costs, and penalty terms for unmet demand are formulated. Then it is embedded in a simulation-based genetic algorithm to handle lead-time variability and random demand. Shelf life is treated as a decision variable, allowing the genetic algorithms to determine optimal discard ages, while disruptions trigger a repricing mechanism parameterized by price‐adjustment factor, recovery rate, and demand elasticity. Computational experiments demonstrate that dynamic shelf-life control cuts waste-related losses by up to 95%, and adaptive repricing restores 85–90% of pre-shock revenue within five days. Sensitivity analyses identify moderate repricing and recovery parameters as the best trade-off between revenue stabilization and demand volatility. This unified approach offers a practical decision-support tool for resilient, cost-effective perishable food supply chain management.

title: Advanced Dynamic Programming Optimization for Real-Time Model Predictive Control in Heat Pump Driven Residential Hvac Systems
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Eurac Research, Trinity College Dublin and Eurac Research

detail.title: Advanced Dynamic Programming Optimization for Real-Time Model Predictive Control in Heat Pump Driven Residential Hvac Systems
detail.abstract: The increasing volatility of electricity prices, driven by the integration of renewable energy sources, necessitates more efficient control strategies for electrified residential heating and cooling systems. This paper proposes an Advanced Dynamic Programming (ADP) algorithm designed for real-time Model Predictive Control (MPC) of heat pump-driven HVAC systems with integrated thermal energy storage (TES). The ADP approach introduces a smart cutoff criterion and brute-force initialization to significantly reduce computational overhead while preserving the global optimality of standard Dynamic Programming (DP).The proposed method is benchmarked against standard DP, Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Genetic Algorithms (GA) in a residential test case based on a German dwelling with time-varying electricity prices. Results show that ADP finds the same cost-optimal control trajectories as DP but with up to 75% less computational time. Compared to metaheuristics, ADP delivers superior cost savings while being up to two orders of magnitude faster, particularly for extended forecast horizons, enabling effective real-time MPC applications. The method is not limited to HVAC applications, but can be used for any MPC problem solvable by DP, enabling more intelligent and resource-efficient energy management under dynamic operating conditions.

title: Frequent Extensions of the Resource-Constrained Project Scheduling Problem: A Systematic Literature Review
affiliations: Deakin University, Deakin University and Deakin University

detail.title: Frequent Extensions of the Resource-Constrained Project Scheduling Problem: A Systematic Literature Review
detail.abstract: At the heart of project management lies the project scheduling problem, which involves arranging a set of activities within a project to ensure timely completion. The majority body of works on the project scheduling problem focus on a variant called the resource-constrained project scheduling problem (RCPSP) considering limited resource availability. The standard RCPSP is known as an NP-hard problem and has attracted significant attention from researchers. Moreover, practical engineering requirements add further complexity to the problem, prompting additional assumptions and various extensions. Recognizing the most attractable extensions plays a pivotal role in helping scholars identify significant real-world challenges. In this survey, the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Metaanalyses (PRISMA) model is adopted for a systematic literature review of RCPSP variants. The main purpose of this study is to provide researchers with a taxonomy and an overview of the frequent extensions of the RCPSP, as well as to identify potential research directions in project scheduling. Employing this approach, we investigate 295 articles selected among thousands published journal articles between 2010 and 2024, and identify three main categories of most frequent RCPSP extensions: multi-skilled RCPSP, RCPSPs under uncertainty, and the multi-project RCPSP. For each category, statistical analyses and summaries of model types and assumptions, solution approaches are presented. Finally, our investigation of the contributions of the reviewed studies yields insights into future research directions.

title: Pareto-Optimal Portfolio Selection Without Convexity: Cross-Efficiency Fdh Models and Machine Learning Integration

detail.title: Pareto-Optimal Portfolio Selection Without Convexity: Cross-Efficiency Fdh Models and Machine Learning Integration
detail.abstract: Portfolio optimization remains a critical challenge in financial decision-making. While Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) offers a multi-criteria framework for evaluating investment efficiency and constructing optimal portfolios, traditional convexity assumptions in DEA models often misrepresent real-world market dynamics. Furthermore, conventional DEA and Free Disposal Hull (FDH) methods suffer from limitations in discriminatory power, stability, and reliability. Addressing these gaps, we propose a novel nonconvex FDH-cross-efficiency analysis algorithm to construct Pareto-efficient portfolios, ensuring optimal performance assessment. Additionally, a machine learning preprocessing stage efficiently screens out a substantial number of assets lacking selection potential prior to portfolio construction, significantly streamlining the optimization process in big data environments. Our approach enhances proactive portfolio management by providing a nonparametric strategy for two important challenges: the big-data challenge and cardinality-constrained portfolio construction. Furthermore, it provides a new bridge between nonconvex cross-efficiency evaluation, machine learning, and portfolio management. In addition to the theoretical results and discussions, our findings are implemented on real-world data from the Tehran Stock Exchange, revealing the applicability and robustness of the proposed results.Highlights¶ Proposing a nonconvex Pareto cross-efficiency method;¶ Providing new theoretical insights on duality in nonconvex FDH models;¶ Developing a machine learning preprocessing step filtering unpromising assets;¶ Constructing Pareto portfolios with real-world constraints;¶ Demonstrating the model’s ability and robustness under real market conditions.

title: Ontology-Driven Digital Twins for Optimized Recommissioning of Hospital Building Operations
affiliations: University of Southern Denmark, University of Southern Denmark and University of Southern Denmark

detail.title: Ontology-Driven Digital Twins for Optimized Recommissioning of Hospital Building Operations
detail.abstract: Optimizing setpoints in non-residential buildings is complex due to competing objectives: energy efficiency, occupant comfort, and cost. This paper presents a multi-objective optimization framework integrated with an ontology-based digital twin for building operation optimization. Using the Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II, the framework balances thermal discomfort, CO2 levels, and energy costs, employing semantic models to define building topology and component constraints. Applied to a hospital case study, the approach reduced thermal discomfort by 92% and energy costs by 48% using a comfort-focused strategy with 73 decision variables selected from a Pareto front. Robustness was validated across unseen operational periods, adapting to occupancy and weather variations. Sensitivity analysis identified space temperature setpoints as primary optimization drivers, followed by supplied air temperature. This scalable framework supports building management system recommissioning by mapping results to controllers, suitable for diverse non-residential buildings.

title: Geographic Proximity of Investors and Firms’ ESG Performance: Evidence on Local Institutional and Retail Investors
affiliations: University of Massachusetts Lowell - Department of Accounting, University of Massachusetts Lowell and University of Massachusetts Lowell - The Robert J. Manning School of Business

detail.title: Geographic Proximity of Investors and Firms’ ESG Performance: Evidence on Local Institutional and Retail Investors
detail.abstract: This article examines how the geographic proximity of investors and the type of local investor impact a firm’s environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance. For each public firm, we infer investors’ geographic distribution from the EDGAR Log File data, which tracks information acquisition activities on the SEC website. We then measure the firm’s ESG performance using MSCI KLD social ratings. We find that a larger proportion of both local institutional and retail investors is positively associated with ESG performance. Further analyses reveal that local retail investors play an important role in enhancing ESG performance for firms with low information asymmetry and strong corporate governance, while local institutional investors are more positively associated with improved ESG performance among firms with high information asymmetry and weak corporate governance. These results suggest that the effects of different types of local investors on ESG performance depend on specific information environments of firms and the strength of corporate governance. Our results further indicate that local institutional and retail investors have heterogeneous impacts on specific ESG components. Finally, we find that local investors play a significant role in strengthening firms’ ESG strengths and mitigating ESG concerns.
